Climate modeling experts can improve the coupling and parameterization of the Energy Exascale Earth System Model (E3SM) and other climate models by applying causal inference methods. Climate models are crucial for understanding climate change. We propose to apply causal inference methods to improve predictions by comparing model outputs with observations of natural phenomena. This approach can help identify areas for improvement, but it requires a systematic method to determine where to focus efforts.

Currently, climate models are developed using a trial-and-error approach, which becomes inefficient for computationally expensive models. We propose to investigate the causal relationships between features and their weights to better target reparameterization and feature selection efforts. The pan-Arctic region is a key area of focus due to previous research on Earth system model (ESM) prediction discrepancies (Nichol et al., 2021). The Arctic climate has significant global implications, and understanding its causal drivers is essential for predicting future climate change.

Causal discovery is a promising approach for improving climate models, as argued in a recent review by Runge et al. (2019a). Nowack et al. (2020) provided an example analysis of a global climate model using causal inference methods. This work aims to extend the application of causal inference to the E3SM model and include multiple feature analysis.

Unlike statistical correlations, causal inference reveals the underlying reasons for system behavior. By discovering the causal structure in data and comparing it with observed and simulated datasets, we can gain a deeper understanding of the differences between the data sources. However, controlling and intervening in the climate for experimentation is challenging due to its complexity and uniqueness.

Climate science relies on coupled numerical models, which encapsulate subsystems and subprocesses that work together to determine the long-term climate. The current approach to evaluating Earth system models is based on simple descriptive statistics, such as mean, variance, and spectral properties of model output derived from correlation and regression methods (Runge et al., 2019a). However, these methods can be ambiguous or misleading, resulting in spurious associations and unknown effect directions.

A rigorous mathematical framework for observational causal inference has been developed, based on Reichenbach's Common Cause Principle (Reichenbach, 1991). This framework identifies the direction of observed effects between variables and detects spurious correlations. The E3SM model, a coupling of atmospheric, ocean, river, land, land ice, and sea ice numerical models, is the focus of this work. The model aims to use exascale computing to output high-resolution simulations of natural and anthropogenic effects in the climate.

The Arctic climate has significant direct and indirect impacts on global climate, ecology, geopolitics, and economics (Hassol, 2004; Richter-Menge et al., 2019; Smith & Stephen, 2013). The volume and extent of Arctic sea ice are important indicators of the current state and projections of global climate change (Goosse et al., 2018; Sevellec et al., 2017; Runge et al., 2015; Cvijanovic et al., 2017). Understanding the causal drivers in the Arctic climate system is essential for predicting the future of our climate and mitigating or intervening in climate change.
